triples.name: Game theory
triples.relevance: The paper applies game theory as a foundation to analyze how behavioral deviations from rational predictions occur and resolve through learning.

triples.name: Behavioral economics
triples.relevance: The paper proposes behavioral game theory to explain systematic deviations from standard economic predictions due to fairness concerns and limited foresight.

triples.name: Economic fairness
triples.relevance: The paper identifies fairness concerns as a key factor explaining why people deviate from purely self-interested behavior predicted by standard game theory.

triples.name: Cooperation
triples.relevance: The paper examines cooperative behavior as a systematic deviation from self-interest in strategic games, observed as people try to cooperate with others.

triples.name: Nash equilibrium
triples.relevance: The paper references game-theoretic equilibrium (Nash equilibrium) as the predicted outcome that behavior converges to with learning and experience.

triples.name: Learning theory
triples.relevance: The paper proposes improved models of the learning process to explain how behavioral deviations disappear as people learn when they can be unfair and what others will do.
